prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to work through this. So the user is asking if the person (the author) is in the wrong for telling their friend that her being single is because she has five kids with different fathers and none of the dads pay child support. The friend had been making a lot of insulting comments over two years, and the author finally snapped.

First, I need to understand the situation. The friend was repeatedly making personal and insulting remarks, which the author tried to brush off. Then, when the friend asked again, the author gave a direct answer pointing out the friend's situation as a reason she's single. The friend got upset, hung up, and mutual friends are now saying the author is wrong and that they have privilege.

So the question is whether the author was in the wrong by making that comment. The possible answers are A (yes) or B (no). 

I should consider the dynamics of the friendship. The author was defending themselves after enduring insults. The friend's questions were not just about her own situation but also directly attacking the author's appearance and lifestyle. The author's response, while honest, could be seen as pointing out a factual issue rather than an insult, but maybe it was still harsh.

However, even if the friend was making the author feel attacked, responding with a comment about her having multiple partners and no support from fathers could be seen as crossing a line. Even if the author's statement is true, the way it was delivered might have been too direct and hurtful, especially since it's a sensitive topic. 

Additionally, the mutual friends are calling the author privileged, which suggests that in their view, the author's comments were insensitive. The author argues they're not privileged and have worked hard, but the friends' reactions indicate that the author's response came off as judgmental. 

It's possible that there was a more constructive way to address the friend's insecurity without pointing out her situation directly. The author might have intended to be honest, but the method could have been hurtful. Even if the friend was provoking, the author's response might have been the wrong approach. 

So, considering all factors, the author might be in the wrong because the response, while perhaps true, was a personal attack that didn't address the friend's issues constructively. The answer would be A (yes).
